text: He operated a bulldozer in Puerto Rico and a hotel on the West Indies. He trained as a circus aerialist to serve three years as a semen and worked in advertising. Now, if you think this sounds like the typical biography of an American author, you're right. His name is Theodore Stagen, but he's not exactly typical. He is numerous stories and novels or chiefly in the area of science fiction or fantasy. He's one of only three writers of one all three of the major science fiction awards, the International Fantasy Award, the Hugo and the Nebula Awards. Mr. Stagen has been in the area attending Conclave 3, a meeting of science fiction writers and fans sponsored by the Eastern Michigan University Science of science fiction society. The Stagen let me leap-feet foremost into this and ask you first what in your view is the major difference between science fiction today and other types of imaginative writing. Well, essentially you're asking me for a definition of science fiction and I have to tell you what the outset. The nobody has yet succeeded into finding science fiction in a way that does not leak with a possible exception of Damon Knight who said science fiction is whatever you happen to be pointing at when you're talking about it. There are those who claim that I have never written a science fiction story in my life. These are the hardcore nuts and bolts, Zap Guns, Space Flight, Hard Chemistry, Hard Biology, Divernd, they don't feel that science fiction is science fiction without it. Are gimmick. That's right. Good science fiction has first of all I think to be good fiction. Good fiction is people. A lot of science fiction does lack that particular quality. Those qualities of compassion and of love and of internal growth and so on where the person is the most important thing. Good fiction is the interaction between people and people or the interaction between people and ideas. If you're interested about an idea only, you might have something very compelling but it's a tracked, it isn't a story. And so I really start from there and this is why as I say I have been accused by the hard course science fiction addicts of not writing real science fiction at all. Yet I have done a lot about spaceflight and about biology and about evolution and so on. Well I sometimes wonder, a friend's a radio like Donald Bartholomey, is not so very far. No, some ways from science fiction. This is a very interesting thing. Science fiction is coming out of its own special ghetto which is live for about 40 years. There's an interesting thing about people who survive ghetto living. They come out strong because if they're going to survive at all, they have to be a little bit stronger. And I think you'll find a larger percentage of good writing and of really fascinating, good inventive thinking in the area of science fiction than you'll find it anywhere else. You see it exploding all around you now. In 1965 there were two courses in science fiction, one in Pennsylvania and one in eastern New Mexico. This year there are close to 3,000 and one of my endeavors that recently has been teaching teachers teaching symposium of teachers science fiction. Because with 3,000 courses there's anybody to teach it without taking a special course. Or what they end up doing is teaching writing really essentially. And there's really nothing wrong with that. Now there's a snob situation involved here too. Vladimir Navikov's last I think it was his last novel called Ada. And it's an alternate universe story and was the Germans won the first World War. It is definitely a science fiction story. Nobody calls Navikov a science fiction writer. Kurt Wannigot Jr refuses to be called a science fiction writer. He's a faded or a fictive sales. And what do you got a man like Thomas Pension writing? Gravity's name is very much like science fiction. It certainly is. And in the right or V is to pinch on. Which also was science fiction. So Dars' last thing is very highly touted literary writing. It's right here when I novel about the London and the future. That's right. Gains the aim is with whom I violently disagree on most points. It did make a very, very good one. When he said that the reaction of the so-called serious critic and the public at large is, Hey, this is science fiction. It can't be good. Or hey, this is good. It can't be science fiction. You have stated elsewhere that you try to alter your style constantly. I wonder about that. Don't you think that every author and consciously identifies himself through a style, what he does all of. Not every author. It's true you can get an offer along the literary business by developing a style and being invented by the Hemingway did it. For example, Bradbury is a perfect example. But you know, with a little bit of study and some natural talent, you can sit down and write one paragraph of perfect Hemingway. One paragraph of perfect Steinbeck. But would you prefer to be identified as yourself as, as, as, as, as, as, as, as, for a while than rather than Bradbury or Hemingway or who. Anyway, yeah, but do you see, I think that that in ways of limitation. There is a distinction between something which is original and something which is unique. Uh, something as original is that something can be done the first time and once people see how it's done, Everybody can do it. Mickey Spelaine was in that sense in original. As soon as he did, what he did by, uh, hundreds of writers started to do the same thing. and Hemingway also was saving a Stein back to a degree, even Kippling, and Robert Lewis Stevenson had a very distinctive style, H.W. H.W. Hager. But just try to write a paragraph and identify a paragraph of Samuel R. Delaney, for example, a science fiction writer of the highest caliber. When he writes Black and Ghetto, it is the real thing. When an novel people are discussing modern American poetry, they do it in the idiom of William Carlos Williams, and he knows what he's talking about. He can change the whole texture and style of what he's saying. And this is a quality that I admire very, very much indeed. You get bogged down sometimes however in the attempt to change your style. No, it's just not natural. Not particularly. I guess it's, I have a good ear. And I'm more interested in people than in anything else. And I listen to people. And I report either what it is they say or what it is I wish they had said. But in the way they say it. And of course eliminating the earth and us and that you're in a crossing. If you've ever read, and I know you have, of course in your business, you would have a type transcript of a speech terrible. It's just awful. You've also been quoted as saying that writing is a way of getting even with people. Now that sounds very pessimistic, misinsropic. And you're definitely not that sort of person yourself. What did you mean by that? Well, I think this is true really of all writers, particularly writers who write, who take their craft seriously. And yet often unbeknownst to the writer himself, he is in that sense getting even. Getting even is not necessarily a vengeful thing. Sometimes it's an attempt to understand why you were hurt. Why did this person hurt me? Is your puzzle, your bewildered. You write a story and before you know it there's a character in who has been hurt in the same way. And from the narrative, even if it's a subplot or a subsidiary line in the story, a reason for that hurt evolves, you begin to understand better. Why you were hurt and perhaps you're recognizing that the fact you deserve to be hurt in that instance. So it isn't particularly a vengeful thing of getting even. It's a question of understanding your fellow human beings. I assume that you've developed some fairly strong opinions, beliefs over the years, whether it be in the area of society or politics or whatever. Do you consciously utilize these beliefs in your stories attempt to grind a certain ax? Let's say. I think rather than trying to persuade anybody else to my way of thinking, I continually attempt to crystallize my own thinking. If there's a flaw in its logic, if there's a prejudice, if there's an unthought conclusion, it becomes open for grabs. And one of my characters is a big example. I expose his bigotry. I mean, I pursue his logic until it becomes ridiculous. Or I do analogies of people. I remember I wrote a story one time about essentially about Joseph McCarthy. It was a parallel story. It was cast in the future dealt with other planets in space, flight, and so on. But I felt very strongly about that at the time. And I had to figure out what it is that the man was doing. Why was he doing what he was doing? I aside from him, of course, he was after a certain amount of power. And there was that within which demanded a lot of public attention. But those things are basically superficial. Why did he want public attention? Why did he want power? What was his motivations there? And so the character was historical Mr. Costello Hero. I went right down to the netty grid. He finally, why a man does a thing like that. Joe McCarthy and so he was a very fascinating man. He had two sets of realities. One of them was the one that stood up in front of the microphones and waived paper in his hands and said, I hold in my hand 240 names of communist and the state department. And another, but naive, kind of almost childlike. I remember when episode was writing an elevator with Richard Rovere, a reporter who did great deal of work on him. And Dean Acheson, a man he had virtually destroyed stepped into the elevator. And McCarthy said, Hey, Dean, how you've been? And I'm very friendly way. Acheson's lives got white, his ears got red. Elevator stopped and he got out. And McCarthy turned Richard Rovere and said, Hey, what's the matter with him? Has he mad at me? And that was, I mean, said in real innocence and absolutely innocence, there's a, there's a part missing in people like that. See, I'm not holding him up as a devil at all. But it's a very, very fascinating kind of human being. It's just a story to an accursed me that a great deal of science fiction writing is is a negativeistic in a way because so many stories deal with utopias and how they fail, but they aren't real utopias. They are ideal societies. I have thought of something, not many people seem to have thought about utopias. You see, let me go back to something like this, the cells in your body are different. At this moment, they were when you walked into the studio. There's a perpetual growth and change within you and with anything that's alive. And for that matter, the planet that we're on, it's started in some coal-lasting gases and it's going to end in a, a bunch of cinders. And the process between us, too, has not stopped. We're sitting on an island of granite, a float on a sea or hot mush on a planet which is in motion around its primary. This sun itself is in motion in the galaxy. The galaxies are all tunneling around in and amongst each other, even the space between us in kind of a turmoil. If you're at timescale as large enough, you can see the whole thing boiling. The only unnatural practice that I can think of, truly unnaturally practice is to stop for a living thing to just stop. And yet there is that about human beings which makes them want to stop. Now we are, where you mentioned utopias, virtually without exception, the utopia is a static situation. You have your own self-tortive goal for everything is all neat and all the buildings that build around the lake and all the, they all have ten stories and, you know, and the people move back and forth and not in smile each other and love each other a bunch. But there's no more beyond that. Maybe internal expansion and I can't knock that. I mean, there's people perhaps are learning more and experiencing more within themselves. Nevertheless, virtually all utopias are playtop, run on up, have this quality of being perfected instruments like pyramids, like the Egyptian pyramids, finished with a single stone on top. Well, life isn't like that. People aren't like that. If I were to design a utopia, it would be one of dynamic equilibrium rather than static. It would be the kind of equilibrium that a girl has when it flies. It has to be in motion in order to remain a lot. All life is like that. There are tenancy to become pessimistic about the future. Not as long as, as I say, we can combat this, this, this hunger for stasis that I think is the human being's greatest disease. He wants it locked in and it's better what you see in the magazine is diamonds or not forever. They really are not forever. Nothing is forever in that sense. And if you can recognize that and design your life and your politics and your morality and a sense of ongoing and evolution and growth and deeper understanding, but always perpetual movement. Then I think you have something like a utopian situation, but it's a dynamic utopia you see. And you know, progress in quotation marks has gotten a bad name at many times in the past. Most of the people who don't like the way progress is going, I mean, there was probably a lot of lip polling about coming down out of the trees, they're out of the caves. It's good enough for my grandfather. It's good enough for you, kid. Many people, I suppose, they are writers mainly, or all those curious about the habits of another writer and the possibility of having writing blocks and we get going and the does he have periods of total letter G and so forth? Do you have any secrets? I am the world's greatest expert on writers' blocks. I had once the last for six years, six years. And you know, when you get wives and children and like that, and the rents do and so on, and your income is writing and you drive for six years. It's pretty rough. Very rough. I think I've entered a say I can cure virtually anybody's writers' block. Because it's something that I haven't evolved myself in very profound. I cannot always cure my own, but I had a profound insight one time. I had a major breakdown in 1965. I mean, I really came to be. It was a close thing. Fortunately, I fell into the hands of somebody who, ideally, he was a surgeon fan. This guy, I swear, he'd read more surgeon than surgeon, he'd written, he could quote old paragraphs, which is more than I can do. And he pointed out in that six-year period of the work that I had done before that. And the work that had done subsequent to that period. Because I was one of the things that was wrong with me. I was being whaling those six years, six years as an off-town yet appeal, it's a prize, or make it have a million bucks. And those six years had gone by and everybody was scarred by it. And so on. And I was mourning that fact in this the last years, and that there would never come back. And so on. He pointed out to me that the quality of work that I had done before that, and what was done afterwards. Not only the quality of the content, he said what I had done before were essentially entertainment. And nobody's knocking entertainment. We need them like we need vitamins. But the stuff that I was doing afterwards was of a totally different assort. He called them therapy stories, well he was a therapist, and that was his particular bias. But it's true. Virtually everything in our written sense then has been about people who were sick and get well, or people who are well and get better, and whatever they are. Well, obviously you were growing during that time. That's the point that he made. He said, you are mourning the fact that the work stopped. He said the work didn't stop. The page has stopped coming out. But he said, that's a triviality. The work continued. And he said, this is documented by the work you've done. And that was a huge thing for me to find out. I mean, I'm never going to get depressed about that again. And if I go through a period where no page has come out for weeks or even months, I'm not particularly concerned. I find it when I'm writing, I'm typing in some strange ways all done. And suddenly I sit down and I write it for 30 hours and I'm typing until I fall a recidelift. I produced 21,000 word novel out without getting up from a desk. But you know, in 18 or 20 hours. And it's all done. And oddly enough, the internal structure of this story, the subsidiary plots, the subsidiary of characters themselves, they're placing of climax and denuma. And so it's all there. It's all finished. You're interrupted me in the middle and asked me, how is this going to end? And in what way I wouldn't be able to tell you. That's a peculiar internal thing. Do you turn to other kinds of stories as relief let's say from science fiction? Not as relief, but often another vehicle will say what I want to say better. And as result, I've written real minds as every, I have book Western stories. And then I can't anybody else's Western story, but there was a legitimate Western story. And yeah, I've written a made great way, well, we're back to the same thing where the addict will say that this dirt and doesn't write real science fiction. No, essentially, I write people's dirt. You've worked in scenarios for films, have you know? Yeah, we're not the West Coast originally, 12 years ago, right, it's an arttrec. And about six I sold four, an air two, which is pretty well-par. And of course, and those two have been showcased very well in the mean thing. They were very successful. They were in Star Trek addicts out there. They were a mock time. For those who are very familiar with Star Trek, which shows where these are. Yeah, a mock time was one of them. The other was called Sure Leave. And they've been very successful. Have you worked on full length feature films? Not specifically, no. One of my stories killed those, which is, I think one of the best stories I ever wrote. I mentioned, I'd write up for six years. In the middle of that six-year period, for nine days, I could write, and I wrote killed those, and it's right first draft exactly where you read it all the way through. And then it shot down again. And it was put by universal pictures. And they made a movie of the week out of it. And it is a dog. It is awful. I mean, really. You can't fault the D9, here's the caterpillar, D9, which is marvelous machine. I'm going to love it with those big machines for years anyhow. I'm still a class I hear you're equipment opportunity. As a person who deals with the imagination, imaginative things, do you think that this emphasis on the visual interpreting all these stories through pictures is detrimental to writing of science fiction? It's hard to say, as a man called Byron Price in New York, who is getting out a whole line of what they call graphics, graphics novels, which are as much pictures as they are as they are prose. And they have something to be said for them. But I think it's essentially a super comic book, that's right. But it's another kind of fiction. I mean, just as there are kinds of music, there's chamber music, there's symphonic music, and there's rock in this country. And each conveys to its audience, what its audience really wants. And so I don't know, I am afraid that people are going to start reading, which is an interesting thing. You know, back in the 15th and 16th century, if a guy worked on shoes, he put a big boot up over his door. And if a guy is sold horses, he put a big horse up over his door. Because people couldn't read. We know we're getting back to that. It's not only watching television all the time, but the international science, and now you've got a sign for the ladies' room and you got a sign for a telephone, and you've got a sign for their baggage, pick up and so on. All these little picture graphs. And pretty soon, we're just going to be watching the tube and looking at pictures grass, and what price really find finished prose. It's quite of the fact that the gimmickry is superior. Do you think we've gone downhill from Star Trek to Battle Star Galactic? Battle Star Galactic has suffered primarily from the ripoff. I mean, they take things that are guaranteed successes and redo them in the Galactic format. For example, Jane and I saw Shane on Battle Star Galactic virtually down the line. And this is what they do. Whatever has been successful, and they put it in the science, fiction, format, and it works. Star Trek was its own highly original thing. The success of Star Trek, the people tried to imitate it and fail. The main reason they fail is that Star Trek was started and promoted and still is by a man who had ideals. He really did. Gene Roddenberry believes in such things as patriotism in American, democratic ideal, and the equality of the sexists, and the equality of the races. He believes in these things very deeply, his own personality, and in every episode of Star Trek, he exploited and expressed these beliefs. And that's really what we each people. It wasn't so much Captain Kirk and Mr. Spock's point of view, it was the underlying faith that had his own idea. A lot of people who say that that's corny and a ho-hom and array, that's wrap ourselves in the American flag. It isn't that it goes very much, even that. People really do want something to believe in. Space 1999 and even Galactic, don't really seem to give much of a damn about anything except getting this show on the year next season. But Gene Roddenberry believed very profoundly in these things using Star Trek to express them from the visual to other art forms. I know you are an appreciator of music. Do you sometimes feel that they're wish that you were a composer rather than a writer, could you express some of your ideas better in some other form? Either as a composer or an artist? There are things that you can say in music that you can't say in words. I am certainly thought of John Carl Mennotti who wrote the medium. As somebody wrote him once as a triple threat artist, he was a director and it was a composer and he was a libretist. And he said, oh no, not triple. Double. And interviewer said, when you mean double, he said, well, yes, I'm a director, but he said as far as the rest of it, the words come to me in music. To him they were all the same thing. It's a very interesting way of expressing it. But sometimes music alone, there's a guitar a2d by Fernando Sour, which someday I'm going to write lyrics too, but it just takes me apart and listen to. I think the greatest piece of music ever composed is the Pasecagli and few you can see mine by Bach. It's architecture in such an extraordinary way. One's up with establishes a 15 note theme and simply repeat it over and over again, but we're rephrasing it and throwing it to various parts of the orchestra, whether he composed it with four and orchestra or not at the beside point. And winding up with a monumental discord, everything is there. He's just a great crashing 115 piece of chord that leans over sideways about to fall over. Then he backs off and it gives it to your in-seat major, having written in-seemime at the whole time. And you just go away feeling good and I don't know how you do that in prose. I really don't. You have a new collection of stories that's just out. Yeah, it's called Vision's Invisionaries. It's from down. It's the first of five works that Dell is getting out within the next year, 18 months. Are both of these short story collections? No, two of them are novels. Two of them are the other three or or you find it more difficult to write a full length work than a short story. It depends on the idea that's pushing you. Often you'll start to write a short story and expands itself into a novel that or even into a novel. That's interesting how that happens to. Often you get a very powerful idea and it plunges you right into it and you keep working it and working it until it's done. You find that it needs to be cut and what you cut is the original idea that started the whole thing because it's taking the bitnits teeth and run off in another direction. The suggestion has been delightful talking with you. Thank you so much for joining us. Thank you. And it's been a pleasure to talk to you. You have some fine questions. You really do. Thank you.
